contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to say that Solomon will keep Adonijah safe. Alternate translation: "not a hair of his head will fall" or "I will keep him safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: not a hair of his will fall to the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: It may be helpful to state that this caused the baby to die. Alternate translation: "accidentally rolled on top of her baby and smothered him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: lay on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Huram accepted Solomon's invitation to come to Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: brought him from Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: A widow is a woman whose husband has died, so we know that the father is dead. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: the son of a widow ... his father was a man of Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: There was one axle for each pair of wheels. Alternate translation: "four bronze wheels and two axles" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.glQuote: four bronze wheels and axles

contextId.occurrenceNote: To "turn someone's heart" is to convince that person to change his affection. See how you translated a similar phrase in [1 Kings 11:1](../11/01.md). Alternate translation: "turned his heart away from Yahweh" or "persuaded him to stop worshiping Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: turned his heart away

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Israel" implicitly means the northern ten tribes that rebelled against Rehoboam. Alternate translation: "king over all of the 10 tribes of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: king over all Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that these were houses of worship. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: "houses of worship on high places" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: houses on high places

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that Yahweh sent the man of God to Bethel. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh sent a man of God from Judah to Bethel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: A man of God came out of Judah by the word of Yahweh to Bethel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that the sons also told their father which way the man of God went. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: his sons had seen the way

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that they were still eating and drinking at the table. Alternate translation: "As they were eating and drinking at the table" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: As they sat at the table

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that these were houses of worship. Alternate translation: "houses of worship on the high places" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: houses on the high places

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the fifth year of Rehoboam's reign as king. Alternate translation: "in the fifth year that Rehoboam was king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: in the fifth year of King Rehoboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the eighteenth year of Jeroboam's reign. Alternate translation: "After Jeroboam had been the king of Israel for almost eighteen years" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam son of Nebat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since these verses refer to several kings, it may help to include the name of Abijah's father. This information can be made clear. AT "that his father, Rehoboam, had committed before Abijah's time" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: that his father had committed before his time

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase represents the time that he was king. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: "before Abijah was king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: his time

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a general way to refer to the situation with Uriah. It can be stated more clearly what this matter was. Alternate translation: "except for what he did to Uriah the Hittite" or "except when he caused Uriah the Hittite to be killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: except only in the matter of Uriah the Hittite

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the twentieth year of Jeroboam's reign. Alternate translation: "After Jeroboam had been the king of Israel for almost twenty years" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: In the twentieth year of Jeroboam king of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the entire time they reigned as kings. Alternate translation: "the whole time that they reigned over Judah and Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: all their days

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the army of Baasha first captured Ramah. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: "captured and fortified Ramah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: built up Ramah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Asa wanted Ben Hadad to attack Israel. Ben Hadad could only do that if he broke his covenant with the king of Israel. The meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: "Break your covenant with Baasha king of Israel, and attack Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Break your covenant with Baasha king of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the second year of Asa's reign. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: "when Asa had been king of Judah for almost two years" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: the second year of Asa king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the whole period of time that they reign as kings. See how you translated this in [1 Kings 15:16](../15/16.md) Alternate translation: "the whole time that they reigned over Judah and Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: all their days

contextId.occurrenceNote: God became angry with the people because they worshiped idols. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: "they made Yahweh, the God of Israel, angry because they worshiped idols" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: they provoked Yahweh, the God of Israel, to anger with their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: This treason refers to Zimri's plot to kill Elah, the king of Israel. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: "how he plotted against King Elah" or "how he killed the king of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: the treason that he carried out

contextId.occurrenceNote: God became angry with the people because they worshiped idols. See how you translated a similar phrase in [1 Kings 16:13](../16/13.md). Alternate translation: "to make Yahweh, the God of Israel, angry because they worshiped worthless idols" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: to provoke Yahweh ... to be angry with their worthless idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that Ahab wanted to commit worse sins. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: "It was as if Ahab thought that walking in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat was not enough" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: It was to Ahab a trivial thing to walk in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they will die because they do not have anymore food. Alternate translation: "that we may eat. Afterwards, we will starve to death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: that we may eat it, and die

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implicit that there would be enough flour and oil to make more bread. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: afterward make some for you and for your son

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elisha gave the cooked meat to the people of his city. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: he gave it to the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is an oath that emphasizes that what follows will not happen. Alternate translation: "Because Yahweh forbids it, I will never give" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: May Yahweh forbid that I should give

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Israel" refers to all twelve tribes of Israel and not just to the northern kingdom. Alternate translation: "removed from the presence of the people of Israel" or "drove out of the land before the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: removed before the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "them" refers to "the words of the prophets." Alternate translation: "let what you say agree with what they have said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: let your word be like one of them

contextId.occurrenceNote: "you will know the answer to your question." If Zedekiah's rhetorical question is translated as a statement, this phrase may be translated to supply implicit information. Alternate translation: "you will know that the Spirit of Yahweh has spoken to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: you will see
